Good little exspansions, roughly 11 chapters although i think 2 of them were so short they really shouldnt be counted as chapters, otherwise a very good little story that ties in with the original half life game showing the soldiers that came in to exterminate the scientists and then you trying to escape as soldiers come into exterminate you and your soldiers. Overall the storyline and gameplay follows the same story and mission objectives as the original game but with way more guns and enemies. Alot faster paced and a few new added features such as climbing ropes to stop it from just being a repeat of the original game. Still really fun and well recommeneded for after you play through the first game.

Mindblow

That was the thing that i felt when i completed this game. I think it's hard to find a game that inverts the story of the original one, put the player into the role of the antagonist party -at least the human antagonist- and still be a good game. Well, Opposing Force turned out to be a fantastic game, besides some bugs that i encountered through my experience it stood well and took a place in my all time favorites.

The story it self, the new protagonist, new allies and foes, new weapons and locations, all of the things mentioned before (and much more) mix and the product is a well paced, action packed story. 

I won't spoil the plot and things that appear in the game, in the end, it's worth a complete run of the game, to find what new dangers a secrets are found in Black Mesa in this visit in the feet -and boots- of Corporal Shepard.

Fajna Gra
My favorite of the spinoffs.

This is the first of the spin-offs to the highly successful Half Life game, when I say "spin-off" I mean that the game is set in the same universe as the original Half Life game except focused on a different protagnogist. Opposing Force is about a marine named Colporal Adrien Shepard of the HECU Marines of the U.S.A. who is part of a platoon given orders from the government to eliminate all witnesses of the Black Mesa incident. Upon arriving at the outer reaches of the lab facility, the chopper Shepard was on got knock down and after that Shepard got knock out cold and eventually awakes inside the Black Mesa health ward. He soon realizes that the lab facility is over run by hostile aliens and various marines as well as Black Mesa staff members are either dead or horribly mutated. What started out as a simple government cover up is now a survival game for Shepard. With the aid of the last surviving marines and lab staff, Shepard must try to escape from Black Mesa, if he can that is. This was a great attempt to extend the Half Life story by introducing a different character witnessing the events of the Black Mesa incident during the same time frame. A few familiar characters reappear in the game including Barney Calhoun who provided aid to Gordon Freeman and the mysterious G-Man whom you encounter in the last game is present in this game where you get to see what he was doing when not being spotted by Gordon. Similar weapons from the previous game are usable along with newer weapons. While familiar enemies are present along with new enemies who didn't appear in the original game that help make this game less of a carbon copy. The flaws from the first Half Life are also in this game, but highly passable as the game has a great story and plenty of new and familiar locations to explore. The plot contains elements straight out of Full Metal Jacket, James Cameron's Aliens, and the first Predator that creates a military filled game that will satisfy military game fans. If you like Half Life, then you will like this game just as much.

"This is what a singleplayer expansion should be." - Me

While modern singleplayer expansions usually just offer new weapons or a new area to explore, this expansion shows the same game and story from the eyes of the enemy. You play as Adrian Shepard, a solider who is stuck in the middle of an alien invasion. Work with other soliders to survive Aliens & Black Ops, who are trying to silence all witnesses and destroy the entire area.

This expansion not only includes the new story and places, but new weapons alien, military, and experimental. Also a new Half Life Multiplayer experience with not only new maps(like Dust from CS 1.6 :D) & weapons, but a Capture the Flag Gamemode.

I recommend this Expansion to anyone who enjoyed Half Life.

An excellent expansion to an already fantastic game; Half-Life: Opposing Force shows another side of the Black Mesa incident. With new weapons, game mechanics, and areas, it's hard to find any flaws outside of the occational glitch. Although I do wish some weapons (like the Barnacle for example) would have gotten some more levels centered around them. This game has some really unique weapons. Half-Life: Opposing Force is a testament to good game design, and an overlooked gem that any Half-Life fan should check out. It may not be quite as long as the original Half-Life, but seeing as it's an expansion, I can forgive it. Take not new developers, this is how you make an expansion pack. Build upon the the pre-existing gameplay by adding new items and areas to explore. If I had to pick a number out of ten to give Half-Life: Opposing Force, I would give it a 9/10. While some glitches are more frustrating than others (like having your soldiers get stuck behind a door, or getting crushed by an elevator that was a few feet away from you), the rest of the game is fantastic and now that it's currently on sale for $1.24, you'd be a fool not to try this out.

Gearbox has done an incredible job with Half-Life: Opposing Force. Playing through the Half-Life story through the eyes of one of the soldiers is very interesting. We get to see many new locations at Black Mesa and we also get to see some of what happens after the events of Half-Life.

The game feels similar to the original but also unique and different. It introduces many new elements which make the combat play out differently to Half-Life such as new enemies, weapons and the introduction of squad mechanics.
The soundtrack is just as good as in the first game despite not being composed by Kelly Bailey (The credits theme is my personal favourite track). 

Overall an amazing expansion that is almost on par with the original and well worth playing.

The main thing you need to know about this game is that it's not a simple retelling of the Half-Life chapters from the military perspective. Opposing Force is a great expansion pack which features new parts of Black Mesa Research Facility, new awesome weapons, new mysterious enemy called Race X and of course its own story that goes parallel to the events of the original Half-Life. 

On the other hand the game suffers from various glitches, the most famous being the Desert Eagle glitch which prevents you from firing this weapon if you've tried to do so underwater. It's a shame that after so many years some of these are still not fixed (and won't be apparently). Also the final boss and conclusion seemed a little bit rushed. 

Pros:
+ Good story
+ New areas, weapons, enemies
+ Barnacle weapon (personal favourite)
+ All the good stuff the original game had

Cons:
- Annoying glitches
- Final boss and ending are rushed
- Little to no information about Race X

Do you like the original Half-Life? Then you definitely should play Opposing Force.

Half-Life: Opposing Force перемер отличного дополнения. Тут и оружия нового завезли и когда проходишь игру то чувствуешь что играешь не в дополнения а в полноценную игру. Сюжет игры показывает произошедшие в чёрной мезе от другого лица и очень хорош. Есть пара жопных моментов которые трепли мои нервы, это стычки с черными оперативниками и в момент где надо идти по подземелью где на тебя сыпеца орда тварей инопланетных но это не так страшно. Динамка в игре лучше чем в Half-Life 1. Нудных моментов стало меньше, Экшона стало больше. С босом не справится разве что ребёнок. Так что игре 8.5/10. В эту игру стоит по играть не пожалеете.

Mit 'Half life: Opposing Force' haben die Entwickler ein völlig neues Kapitel von Black Mesa aufgeschlagen. Im Gegensatz zu 'Half life: Blue Shift' und 'Half life' (was einfach nur genial ist)  spielt man nun auf der Seite der Soldaten, die den Auftrag haben Gordon Freeman zu töten.

Es folgt eine Pro-/ und Contraliste:

+ Rauer Militär Stil
+ SUPER Half life Atmosphäre
+ G-man hat wieder eine größere Rolle
+ An manchen Stellen eine richtige Herausforderung (auf Schwer)
+ viele Parallelen zum Hauptspiel
+ gutes Ende (bietet Platz für einen zweiten Teil)
+ großes Arsenal an Waffen
+ völlig neue Bereiche der Forschungseinrichtung erkunden
+ Interaktion mit anderen Soldaten (Schweißer, Medic, usw.)

- viele könnten die Grafik heutzutage für zu schlecht befinden. Ich finde sie genau richtig.
- Das 'Soldaten-Folge-System' hängt manchmal
- keine deutsche Uncut. Man muss das Spiel auf Englisch umstellen.

Fazit: Das Spiel ist wie auch schon wie zuvor Half life einfach nur genial gemacht und die Atmosphäre geht richtig ins Blut.
作为一部外传，对原作的补完还不错（虽然没中文语音有点蛋疼，而且准星有跑偏BUG）。流程虽没原作长，但有战友和爬绳子两种充分体现军人特征的新元素很棒，难度不大，就是小怪比BOSS难打。

After finishing "Half-Life," I decided to go and see what was done to improve upon the original game. I first started with this game, "Half-Life: Opposing Force." And when I played it, this game was a testament to how Expansion Packs were in their day, before the age of DLC. It expands upon the original game, with a good story and plenty of new stuff to make it feel like it's own game. This is what I remember fondly about expansion packs from back in the 1990s-2000s. 

Maintaining what made the original "Half-Life" work in the first place, "Half-Life: Opposing Force" is a concurrent story that takes place at the same time as the main game itself.

This time, you play as Marine Corporal Adrian Shephard, who is part of the Marine Hazardous Environment Combat Unit (HECU) as they move to "cleanse" the Black Mesa facility during the events of the original "Half-Life." This game does a great job bridging together moments between this game and the original, making it feel like it's taking place during the main story. Again, Shephard is not a speaking protagonist, making him more immersive to the player. And again, you never lose control of Shephard throughout the game, therefore making it be told completely through his perspective.  What worked very well in the first game works very well in this Expansion. 

Also, the game continues to keep the game's areas interconnected, allowing you to feel like you're travelling through the Black Mesa facility. It again, worked in the first game, and works well in this one.

I also liked the new weapons in this game, a Desert Eagle, a Sniper Rifle, a SAW, some new alien weapons, and even one of those Barnacles. There's plenty of new content and new areas to explore in this game that keep it fresh.

I honestly found myself enjoying this game more than I did the original "Half-Life", and it felt like it corrected several of the flaws the original had. For one, the game doesn't give you as hard a time trying to maintain the power levels of the PCV. Also, the game avoids death-trap level design as much as the original did. There's still plenty of platforming with bad jump controls, but overall, I didn't have as many problems with this game as I did the original. I still like the original, but I feel this game felt more perfected. 

I also liked how this game gave you more useful allies (security guards and scientists aren't much help except for opening doors), but the other Marines in this game are a little more useful (especially the Engineer and Medic), but I found myself preferring to work alone, as the AI for the other Marines makes them not at all that useful in combat. 

Also, the enemy variety is improved quite a bit in this game, especially the Race X aliens, which also add on to the variety. This is another thing that makes this game a true testament to the expansion pack. 

It's a shame that most DLC doesn't have the quality that most old-time Expansion Packs did, but this game is a testament to the expansion pack of the 1990s-2000s. It has plenty of new content, enough of a story, plenty of new enemies, and improves on the original game's flaws. This is a great expansion that I enjoyed greatly. I look forward to another playthrough.

Unlike Blue Shift, Opposing Force almost feels like a different game in some ways than Half Life (even though it is, essentially, playing more of the same of Half Life). You play as a soldier, you have more weapons to pick up and use, and fight more enemy types. It's not as short as Blue Shift and it's much more challenging. Give it a shot if you enjoyed the main game.
